findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop the sales for all users excluding the owner. The owner may take advantage of it by setting the `SellFee` to a high value.

findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25%. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `setBuyFee` or the `setSellFee` function with a high percentage value.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `blacklistAddress` function.

findings.title: PAV - Pair Address Validation
findings.description: The contract is missing address validation in the pair address argument, which can introduce security risks and potential attacks.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract updates the whitelisted status of an account even if its current state is the same as the one passed as an argument. As a result, the contract performs redundant storage writes.

findings.title: URC - Update Router Concern
findings.description: The contract allows modification of the router address without adding the new pair address to the `automatedMarketMakerPairs` mapping, leading to unexpected behavior and potential issues with the contract's functionality.

findings.title: RES - Redundant Event Statement
findings.description: The `InvestFundAddressChanged` event statement is not used in the contract's implementation.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 have native functionality that replaces it.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow the Solidity naming conventions, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be error-prone and requires careful testing and debugging to ensure correctness.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L22 - Potential Locked Ether
findings.description: The contract contains Ether that has been placed into a Solidity contract and is unable to be transferred, potentially producing a financial loss for users.
